item.name: Tool
entries: This entry is a catchall for basic hand tools that don’t have a specific adventuring purpose.

variants.name: Long Tool
entries: A hoe, shovel, or sledgehammer is a long tool. A long tool can usually be used as an improvised weapon, dealing {@damage 1d6} damage. The GM determines the damage type that’s appropriate or adjusts the damage if needed.

variants.name: Short Tool
entries: A hand drill, ice hook, or trowel is a short tool. A short tool can usually be used as an improvised weapon, dealing {@damage 1d4} damage. The GM determines the damage type that’s appropriate or adjusts the damage if needed.

item.name: Writing Set
entries: Using a writing set, you can draft correspondence and scribe scrolls. A set includes stationery, including a variety of paper and parchment, as well as ink, a quill or ink pen, sealing wax, and a simple seal.

variants.name: Extra Ink and Paper
entries: If you’ve written a large amount, you can refill your kit with extra ink and paper.

item.name: Thieves’ Toolkit
entries: You need a thieves’ toolkit to {@action Pick Lock|PC1|Pick Locks} or {@action Disable Device|PC1|Disable Devices} (of some types) using the {@skill Thievery|Pc1} skill. If you wear your thieves’ toolkit, you can draw and replace it as part of the action that uses it.
{@note * You can use a toolkit with 1 hand if you’re wearing it or 2 if you’re holding it.}
If your thieves’ toolkit is broken, you can repair it by replacing the lock picks with replacement picks appropriate to your toolkit; this doesn’t require using the {@action Repair|PC1} action.
An infiltrator thieves’ toolkit adds a +1 item bonus to checks to {@action Pick Lock|PC1|Pick Locks} and {@action Disable Device|PC1|Disable Devices}.
If your thieves’ toolkit is broken, you can repair it by replacing the lock picks with replacement picks appropriate to your toolkit; this doesn’t require using the {@action Repair|PC1} action.

item.name: Religious Symbol
entries: This piece of wood or silver is emblazoned with an image representing a deity. Some {@trait divine} spellcasters, such as {@class cleric|PC1|clerics}, can use a religious symbol to use certain abilities. A religious symbol can be worn on the body on a chain or pin, or can be held.

item.name: Repair Toolkit
entries: A repair toolkit allows you to perform simple repairs while traveling. It contains a portable anvil, tongs, woodworking tools, a whetstone, and oils for conditioning leather and wood. You can use a repair toolkit to {@action Repair|PC1} items using the {@skill Crafting|PC1} skill. You can draw and replace a worn repair toolkit as part of the action that uses it.

variants.name: Superb Repair Toolkit
entries: A superb repair kit gives you a +1 item bonus to the check.

item.name: Spyglass
entries: A typical spyglass lets you see eight times farther than normal.

variants.name: Fine Spyglass
entries: A fine spyglass adds a +1 item bonus to {@skill Perception|PC1} checks to notice details at a distance.
Picking a poor lock requires two successful DC 15 Thievery checks.
Picking a simple lock requires three successful DC 20 Thievery checks.
Picking an average lock requires fpir successful DC 25 Thievery checks.
Picking a good lock requires five successful DC 30 Thievery checks.
Picking a superior lock requires six successful DC 40 Thievery checks.

item.name: Manacles
entries: You can manacle someone who is willing or otherwise at your mercy as an exploration activity taking 10–30 seconds depending on the creature’s size and how many manacles you apply. A two-legged creature with its legs bound takes a −15-foot circumstance penalty to its Speeds, and a two-handed creature with its wrists bound has to succeed at a DC 5 flat check any time it uses a {@trait manipulate} action or else that action fails. This DC may be higher depending on how tightly the manacles constrain the hands. A creature bound to a stationary object is {@condition immobilized|PC1}. For creatures with more or fewer limbs, the GM determines what effect manacles have, if any.
Freeing a creature from poor manacles requires two successful DC 17 Thievery checks.
Freeing a creature from simple manacles requires three successful DC 22 Thievery checks.
Freeing a creature from average manacles requires four successful DC 27 Thievery checks.
Freeing a creature from good manacles requires five successful DC 32 Thievery checks.
Freeing a creature from superior manacles requires six successful DC 42 Thievery checks.

Handheld instruments include bagpipes, a small set of chimes, small drums, fiddles and viols, flutes and recorders, small harps, lutes, trumpets, and similarly sized instruments. The GM might rule that an especially large handheld instrument (like a tuba) has greater Bulk.

Handheld instruments include bagpipes, a small set of chimes, small drums, fiddles and viols, flutes and recorders, small harps, lutes, trumpets, and similarly sized instruments. The GM might rule that an especially large handheld instrument (like a tuba) has greater Bulk.
A virtuoso instrument is more finely made and gives a +1 item bonus to {@skill Performance|PC1} checks using that instrument.
Heavy instruments such as large drums, a full set of chimes, and keyboard instruments are less portable and generally need to be stationary while being played.
Heavy instruments such as large drums, a full set of chimes, and keyboard instruments are less portable and generally need to be stationary while being played.
A virtuoso instrument is more finely made and gives a +1 item bonus to {@skill Performance|PC1} checks using that instrument.

item.name: Lantern
entries: A lantern sheds bright light and requires 1 pint of oil to function for 6 hours.
A bull’s-eye lantern emits its light in a 60-foot cone (and dim light in the next 60 feet).

A hooded lantern sheds light in a 30-foot radius (and dim light in the next 30 feet) and is equipped with shutters, which you can close to block the light. Closing or opening the shutters takes an Interact action.

item.name: Fishing tackle
entries: This kit include a collapsible fishing pole, fishhooks, line, lures, and a fishing net.

variants.name: Professional Fishing Tackle
entries: Professional fishing tackle grants a +1 item bonus to checks to fish.

item.name: Healer’s Toolkit
entries: This kit of bandages, herbs, and suturing tools is necessary for {@skill Medicine|PC1} checks to {@action Administer First Aid|PC1}, {@action Treat Disease|PC1}, {@action Treat Poison|PC1}, or {@action Treat Wounds|PC1}. If you wear your healer’s toolkit, you can draw and replace them as part of the action that uses them.
{@note * You can use a toolkit with 1 hand if you’re wearing it or 2 if you’re holding it.}

variants.name: Expanded Healer’s Toolkit
entries: Expanded healer’s toolkits provide a +1 item bonus to such checks.

item.name: Disguise Kit
entries: This small wooden box contains cosmetics, false facial hair, spirit gum, and a few simple wigs. You usually need a disguise kit to set up a disguise in order to {@action Impersonate|PC1} someone using the {@skill Deception|PC1} skill. You can draw and replace a worn disguise kit as part of the action that uses it.

variants.name: Replacement Cosmetics
entries: If you’ve crafted a large number of disguises, you can replenish your cosmetics supply with replacement cosmetics suitable for the type of your disguise kit.

variants.name: Elite Disguise Kit
entries: An elite disguise kit adds a +1 item bonus to relevant checks.

variants.name: Elite Cosmetics
entries: If you’ve crafted a large number of disguises, you can replenish your cosmetics supply with replacement cosmetics suitable for the type of your disguise kit.

item.name: Compass
entries: A compass helps you {@action Sense Direction|PC1} or navigate, provided you’re in a location with uniform magnetic fields. Without a compass, you take a –2 item penalty to these checks (similar to using a shoddy item).

variants.name: Lensatic Compass
entries: A lensatic compass gives you a +1 item bonus to these checks.

item.name: Crowbar
entries: When {@action Force Open|PC1|Forcing Open} an object that doesn’t have an easy grip, a crowbar makes it easier to gain the necessary leverage. Without a crowbar, prying something open takes a –2 item penalty to the {@skill Athletics|PC1} check to {@action Force Open|PC1}.

variants.name: Levered Crowbar
entries: A levered crowbar grants you a +1 item bonus to {@skill Athletics|PC1} checks to {@action Force Open|PC1} anything that can be pried open.

item.name: Climbing Kit
entries: This satchel includes {@item rope (50 feet)|PC1|50 feet of rope}, pulleys, a dozen {@item piton|PC1|pitons}, a {@item hammer|PC1|h}ammer, a {@item grappling hook|PC1}, and one set of crampons. Climbing kits allow you to attach yourself to the wall you’re {@action Climb|PC1|Climbing}, moving half as quickly as usual (minimum 5 feet) but letting you attempt a DC 5 flat check whenever you critically fail to prevent a fall. A single kit has only enough materials for one climber; each climber needs their own kit. If you wear your climbing kit, you can access it as part of a {@action Climb|PC1} action.

variants.name: Extreme Climbing Kit
entries: You gain a +1 item bonus to {@skill Athletics|PC1} checks to {@action Climb|PC1} while using an extreme climbing kit.
Ordinary clothing is functional with basic tailoring, such as peasant garb, monk’s robes, or work clothes.

Explorer’s clothing is sturdy enough that it can be reinforced to protect you, even though it isn’t a suit of armor. It comes in many forms, though the most common resemble {@class cleric|PC1|clerical} vestments, {@class monk|PC2|monk’s} garments, or {@class wizard|PC1|wizard’s} robes, as members of these classes likely avoid wearing armor.
More expensive finery or clothes for specific climes cost more.
More expensive finery or clothes for specific climes cost more.
More expensive finery or clothes for specific climes cost more.

item.name: Artisan’s Toolkit
entries: You need this toolkit to create items from raw materials with the {@action Craft|PC1} action. Different sets are needed for different work, as determined by the GM; for example, a blacksmith’s toolkit differs from a woodworker’s toolkit. If you wear your artisan’s toolkit, you can draw and replace it as part of the action that uses it.

variants.name: Sterling Artisan’s Toolkit
entries: A sterling artisan’s toolkit gives you a +1 item bonus to the check.

item.name: Alchemist’s Lab
entries: You need an alchemist’s lab to {@action Craft|PC1} {@trait alchemical} items during {@trait downtime}.

variants.name: Expanded Alchemist's Lab
entries: An expanded alchemist’s lab gives a +1 item bonus to {@skill Crafting|PC1} checks to create {@trait alchemical} items.

item.name: Concealed Sheath
entries: This leather sheath is large enough to hold an item of up to light Bulk and is typically used for {@item dagger|PC1|daggers}, {@trait wand||wands}, {@item thieves' toolkit (generic)|PC1|thieves’ toolkits}, and similar objects. You can affix it to the inside of a boot, under a bracer or sleeve, or in other inconspicuous locations to gain a +1 item bonus to {@skill Stealth|PC1} checks and DCs to hide or conceal the item within.

item.name: Adventurer’s Pack
entries: This item is the starter kit for an adventurer, containing the essential items for exploration and survival. The Bulk value is for the entire pack together, but see the descriptions of individual items as necessary.

The pack contains the following items: a {@item backpack|PC1}, a {@item bedroll|PC1}, {@item chalk|PC1|10 pieces of chalk}, {@item flint and steel|PC1}, {@item rope (50 feet)|PC1|50 feet of rope}, 2 weeks’ {@item rations|PC1}, {@item soap|PC1}, 5 {@item torch|PC1|torches}, and a {@item waterskin|PC1}.

item.name: Alchemist’s Toolkit
entries: This mobile collection of vials and chemicals can be used for simple alchemical tasks. If you wear your alchemist’s toolkit, you can draw and replace them as part of the action that uses them.
{@note * You can use a toolkit with 1 hand if you’re wearing it or 2 if you’re holding it.}

item.name: Backpack
entries: A backpack holds up to 4 Bulk of items, and the first 2 Bulk of these items don’t count against your Bulk limits. If you’re carrying or stowing the pack rather than wearing it on your back, its Bulk is light instead of negligible.

item.name: Basic Crafter’s Book
entries: This book contains formulas for {@action Craft|PC1|Crafting} the 0-level common items in this chapter.

item.name: Brass Ear
entries: A brass ear is a short, flared tube with one end narrow enough to comfortably fit against the ear canal. When using it to listen through a door, window, thin wall, or similar barrier, if the barrier would normally increase the DC of your {@skill Perception|PC1} check to hear sounds on the other side, the DC increases by only half as much as normal. It’s not suitable for improving your hearing in general, a role better served by a {@item hearing aid (generic)|PC1|hearing aid}.

item.name: Caltrops
entries: These four-pronged metal spikes can damage a creature’s feet. You can scatter caltrops in an empty square adjacent to you with an {@action Interact|PC1} action. The first creature that moves into that square must succeed at a DC 14 {@skill Acrobatics|PC1} check or take {@damage 1d4} piercing damage and 1 {@condition persistent damage|PC1|persistent bleed damage}. A creature taking {@condition persistent damage|PC1|persistent bleed damage} from caltrops takes a –5-foot penalty to its Speed. Spending an {@action Interact|PC1} action to pluck the caltrops free reduces the DC to stop the bleeding. Once a creature takes damage from caltrops, enough are ruined that other creatures moving into the square are safe. Deployed caltrops can be salvaged and reused if no creatures took damage from them. Otherwise, enough are ruined that they can’t be salvaged.

item.name: Candle
entries: A lit candle sheds dim light in a 10-foot radius for 8 hours.

item.name: Chest
entries: A wooden chest can hold up to 8 Bulk of items.

item.name: Detective’s Kit
entries: This leather satchel contains empty vials, a pair of tweezers, a supply of small linen cloths, a set of brass calipers and a knotted string for measuring distances, several pieces of chalk, a pen, and a blank notebook for keeping notes. Every component of a detective’s kit is of exceeding quality, and thus a detective’s kit adds a +1 item bonus to checks to investigate a crime scene, a clue, or similar details. Like other tool kits, a detective’s kit uses one hand if wearing the kit and two hands otherwise.
{@note * You can use a toolkit with 1 hand if you’re wearing it or 2 if you’re holding it.}

item.name: Dueling Cape
entries: You can pull a dueling cape you’re wearing from your shoulder and wrap it around your arm with an {@action Interact|PC1} action. While wielding the dueling cape this way, the cape uses that arm and hand, and you can’t hold anything else in that hand. While you do so, you can spend an action to hold it in a protective position, giving you a +1 circumstance bonus to AC and to {@skill Deception|PC1} checks to {@action Feint|PC1} until the start of your next turn.

item.name: Flint and Steel
entries: Flint and steel are useful in creating a fire if you have the time to catch a spark, though using them is typically too time-consuming to be practical during an encounter. Even in ideal conditions, using flint and steel to light a flame requires using at least 3 actions, and often significantly longer.

item.name: Formula Book (Blank)
entries: A formula book holds the formulas necessary to make items other than the {@trait common} equipment from this chapter; characters of the {@class alchemist|PC2} class typically get one for free. Each formula book can hold the formulas for up to 100 different items. Formulas can also appear on parchment sheets, tablets, and almost any other medium; there’s no need for you to copy them into a specific book as long as you can keep them on hand to reference them.

item.name: Grappling Hook
entries: You can throw a grappling hook with a rope tied to it to make a climb easier. To anchor a grappling hook, make a ranged attack roll using your simple weapon proficiency against a DC depending on the target, typically at least DC 20. This attack has the {@trait secret} trait. On a success, your hook has a firm hold, but on a critical failure, the hook seems like it will hold but actually falls when you’re partway up.

item.name: Magnifying Glass
entries: This quality handheld lens gives you a +1 item bonus to {@skill Perception|PC1} checks to notice minute details of documents, fabric, and the like.

item.name: Net
entries: You can use a net either on its own or attached to a rope. When attached to a rope, you can use the net to {@action Grapple|PC1} a {@trait Medium} or smaller creature up to 10 feet away (instead of only adjacent creatures). You can continue to {@action Grapple|PC1} to keep your hold on the target so long as the target remains within 10 feet and you continue to hold the net. The {@condition grabbed|PC1} creature gains a +2 circumstance bonus to {@action Escape|PC1} unless you are adjacent to them, and it can attempt a DC 16 {@skill Athletics|PC1} check to {@action Force Open|PC1} the net entirely. Once the target is no longer {@condition grabbed|PC1}, the net is unwieldy until refolded with an {@action Interact|PC1} action with the concentrate trait that requires two hands; if used without being refolded, {@action Grapple|PC1} checks made with the net take a –2 penalty.

When the net is unattached, you can attempt a ranged attack roll using your simple weapon proficiency against a {@trait Medium} or smaller creature within 20 feet. On a hit, the target is {@condition off-guard|PC1} and takes a –10-foot circumstance penalty to its Speeds until it {@action Escape|PC1|Escapes}, and on a critical hit, it’s also {@conditoin immobilized|PC1} until it {@action Escape|PC1|Escapes}. The {@action Escape|PC1} DC is 16. A creature adjacent to the target can {@action Interact|PC1} to remove the net.

item.name: Oil
entries: You can use oil to fuel lanterns, but you can also set a pint of oil aflame and throw it. You must first spend an {@action Interact|PC1} action preparing the oil, then throw it with another action as a ranged attack. If you hit, it splatters on the creature or in a single 5-foot square you target. You must succeed at a DC 10 flat check for the oil to ignite successfully when it hits. If the oil ignites, the target takes {@damage 1d6} fire damage.

item.name: Parrying Scabbard
entries: You can draw this reinforced sheath during the same {@action Interact|PC1} action you use to draw the weapon it holds, wielding the weapon in one hand and the scabbard in your other. A parrying scabbard can be used for your defense much like a weapon with the {@trait parry} trait: you can spend an action to position it defensively, gaining a +1 circumstance bonus to AC until the start of your next turn. Parrying scabbards are available for any {@group sword|PC1} that can be wielded in one hand.

item.name: Periscope
entries: This is a 2-foot-long tube with two angled mirrors, one at each end. When the mirrors are aligned correctly, you can look around obstacles while remaining behind cover. This doesn’t provide a sufficient line of effect to target creatures around corners.

item.name: Piton
entries: These small spikes can be used as anchors to make climbing easier. To affix a piton, you must hold it in one hand and use a hammer to drive it in with your other hand. You can attach a rope to the hammered piton so that you don’t fall all the way to the ground on a critical failure while {@action Climb|PC1|Climbing}.

item.name: Primal Symbol
entries: {@trait Primal} spellcasters, especially {@class druid|PC1|druids}, often wear adornments of natural materials to symbolize their connection to nature, such as rings of woven plants, tokens made from animal parts, or other symbols related to a druidic order or nature philosophy.

item.name: Religious Text
entries: This manuscript contains scripture of a particular religion. Some {@trait divine} spellcasters, such as {@class cleric|PC1|clerics}, can use a religious text to use certain abilities. A religious text must be held in one hand to use it.

item.name: Sack (5)
entries: A sack can hold up to 8 Bulk worth of items. A sack containing 2 Bulk or less can be worn on the body, usually tucked into a belt. You can carry a sack with one hand, but must use two hands to transfer items in and out.

item.name: Saddlebags
entries: Saddlebags come in a pair. Each can hold up to 3 Bulk of items, and the first 1 Bulk of items in each doesn’t count against your mount’s Bulk limit. The Bulk value given is for saddlebags worn by a mount. If you are carrying or stowing saddlebags, they count as 1 Bulk instead of light Bulk.

item.name: Signal whistle
entries: When sounded, a signal whistle can be heard clearly up to half a mile away across open terrain.

item.name: Spellbook (blank)
entries: A spellbook holds the written knowledge necessary to learn and prepare various spells, a necessity for {@class wizard|PC1|wizards} (who typically get one for free) and a useful luxury for other spellcasters looking to learn additional spells. Each spellbook can hold up to 100 spells.

item.name: Tack
entries: Tack includes all the gear required to outfit a riding animal, including a saddle, bit and bridle, and stirrups if necessary. Especially large or oddly shaped animals might require specialty saddles. These can be more expensive or hard to find, as determined by the GM. The Bulk value given is for tack worn by a creature. If carried, the Bulk increases to 2.

item.name: Ten-foot pole
entries: When wielding this long pole, you can use {@action Seek|PC1} to search a square up to 10 feet away. The pole is not sturdy enough to use as a weapon.

item.name: Waterskin
entries: When it’s full, a waterskin contains roughly 1 day’s worth of water for a Small or Medium creature.

item.name: Scholarly Journal
entries: Each scholarly journal is a folio on a very specific topic, such as {@trait vampire||vampires} or the history of a single town or neighborhood of a city. If you spend 1 minute referencing an academic journal before attempting a skill check to {@action Recall Knowledge|PC1} about the subject, you gain a +1 item bonus to the check. The GM determines what scholarly journals are available in any location.

variants.name: Scholarly journal compendium
entries: A compendium of journals costs five times as much as a single journal and requires both hands to use; each compendium contains several journals and grants its bonus on a broader topic, such as all {@trait undead} or a whole city.

item.name: Survey Map
entries: Most maps you can find are simple and functional. A survey map details a single location in excellent detail. One of these maps gives you a +1 item bonus to {@skill Survival|PC1} checks and any skill checks to {@action Recall Knowledge|PC1}, provided the checks are related to the location detailed on the map. The GM determines what maps are available in any location.

variants.name: Survey Map Atlas
entries: Maps sometimes come in atlases, containing a number of maps of the same quality, often on similar topics. An atlas costs five times as much as a single map and requires both hands to use.

item.name: Wheelchair
entries: A common wheelchair is ideal for everyday use but isn't designed for strenuous activity. These wheelchairs are most common among non-adventurers. Wheelchairs come in a variety of sizes to suit every person regardless of height or body type.

variants.name: traveler's chair
entries: A traveler's chair is tailored for frequent adventures and travels. The design is sleek and fashionable to provide excellent comfort and support. A traveler's chair has small mechanisms, either made from interlocking wood pieces, clockwork, or other devices, that allow the chair to traverse up or down stairs without any additional difficulty (moving up stairs is still difficult terrain, just like for other characters), and move through other common adventuring terrain without any additional difficulty, such as ladders and uneven ground.

variants.name: chair storage
entries: Chair storage can be purchased and applied to any wheelchair. This reduces the amount of Bulk the items weigh when stored within the chair, much like a {@item backpack|PC1}. The first 2 Bulk of items stowed in your chair don't count against your Bulk limit. If you use both chair storage and a {@item backpack|PC1} at the same time, only 2 Bulk total isn't counted against your limit, much like if you used multiple {@item backpack|PC1|backpacks} or similar items at the same time.

item.name: Hearing aid
entries: A hearing aid is worn in the ear and is made from carved wood, shaped metal, or even small clockwork pieces. The shape of the device aids those who are hard of hearing, and you can wear one or two depending on your hearing loss. You can attach or remove your hearing aids as an {@action Interact|PC1} action.

A magical hearing aid has the magical trait. With its curved shape, it hooks over the top and sits behind your ear, with a receiver that fits into the ear opening. The external part of the device detects sound waves and, using magic, transfers them down the receiver and into your ear. You can wear one or two depending on your hearing loss, and you can turn your hearing aids on or off using an {@action Interact|PC1} action.

item.name: Cane
entries: A cane is a straight length of wood with a curved handle, shaped like the tip of a hook. Its simple design helps with balance and only slightly assists with taking weight off the affected opposite leg. The cane is typically 2 to 3 feet long but can be lengthened or shortened as needed.

item.name: Corrective Lenses
entries: A set of corrective lenses might take the form of eyeglasses or specialized goggles worn over the eyes. You can don or remove your corrective lenses as an Interact action.

item.name: Crutch
entries: Crutches come as singles or as a pair depending on how much support you need while walking. A crutch fits under your armpit, and you use your hand and the swing of your arm to move with them.

item.name: Prosthesis
entries: A prosthesis replaces a missing or damaged body part. Typical prostheses include artificial feet, eyes, hands, and limbs, though a basic prosthesis can be designed as a replacement for any body part. Advancements in the prosthetic field mean that even the most basic of prostheses can provide the full range of functionality for a missing body part.
A prosthesis has a number of belts or cuffs that keep it attached to your body. You can attach or remove a prosthesis as an {@action Interact|PC1} action.

item.name: Heavy Barding
entries: You can purchase special armor for animals, called barding. Combat-trained animals are trained in heavy barding. Barding uses the same rules as armor except for the following. The Price and Bulk of barding depend on the animal's size (use statistics for Small barding for creatures below Small size). Barding can't be etched with magic runes, though special barding might be available.

item.name: Light Barding
entries: You can purchase special armor for animals, called barding. All animals have a trained proficiency rank in light barding. Barding uses the same rules as armor except for the following. The Price and Bulk of barding depend on the animal's size (use statistics for Small barding for creatures below Small size). Barding can't be etched with magic runes, though special barding might be available.
